properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: continuing through Thursday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: much of western, central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate for the next couple of days. Temperatures are expected to turn cooler Friday as showery weather arrives. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-06-24T17:37:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T01:38:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1232556929.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This evening, conditions will be favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Boaters may be caught off guard by strong gusts on smaller bodies of water. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T07:13:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T02:53:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1230514414.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain continuing tonight. Rain, at times heavy, will continue tonight before easing to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm are expected by Wednesday morning over most areas. Locally higher rainfall amounts over 100 mm are expected as some areas such as Sault Ste. Marie have already reported over 100 mm. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T18:52:28-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing tonight. Heavy rain will continue tonight into Wednesday. Rain is expected to ease to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are expected by Wednesday evening for areas east of Kapuskasing. Local amounts exceeding 50 mm are also possible in this area. Environment and Climate Change Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when rainfall amounts of 50 mm or more are expected in 24 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 9:02 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. This severe thunderstorm is located north of Huntsville, moving northeast at 50 km/h. Hazards: Heavy downpours leading to localized flash flooding. Risk of a tornado. Wind gusts of 70 km/h. Locations impacted include: Burk's Falls, Arrowhead Provincial Park, Big East River Provincial Park and surrounding areas. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-24T04:40:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T01:03:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0319900754.2020
Area: South River - Burk's Falls, Western Algonquin Park - Lake of Two Rivers, Huntsville - Baysville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and torrential rain. Hazards: - damaging wind gusts near 90 km/h - torrential rain giving 50 mm in an hour or less Locations: Leeds and Grenville County, portions of Lanark County and areas east including the National Capital Region. Timing: This evening. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 7:24 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. There is a severe thunderstorm located 40 km southeast of St Paul. This storm is moving eastwards at 40 km/h. This storm gave quarter sized hail at St Paul earlier this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
